title: Pizza restaurant posts pictures of couple who complained about 'two-hour wait'
text:

A pizza restaurant posted CCTV images of a couple, who complained about waiting almost two hours for their food, and accused them of trying to do a runner.

The row erupted when Arron May and his partner became fed up with the wait and were unhappy with their “greasy and very fatty” pizzas.

Mr May said they considered leaving La Pizza, in Derby, without paying but decided to settle the full bill - just under £30 - because they weren't sure of their rights.

But after they left, restaurant boss Antonio Palermo posted the images and claimed the couple were “very rude” and “didn’t want to pay” for their meal, DerbyshireLive reports.

He claims the restaurant didn't do anything wrong by posting the photos online.

(Image: derbytelegraph.co.uk)

Mr Palermo, who wasn't at the restaurant when the couple visited, said it wasn't illegal to post the photos on Facebook alongside claims that Mr May and his partner had tried to avoid paying their bill.

The CCTV images were no longer visible on the restaurant's Facebook page on Saturday.

Mr May said they waited an hour and 45 minutes for their main courses on October 5.

He said they asked the waitress where there food was 50 minutes after ordering, and she apologised and said it would be another 10 minutes.

But after another 30 minutes they asked again and were told it would just be another two minutes, he added.

(Image: derbytelegraph.co.uk)

Mr May claims the pizzas arrived an hour and 45 minutes after they sat down at the table, and he ate his but his partner had lost her appetite by then.

He claims he asked to speak to a manager but was told that one wasn't available, and when he asked to have the drinks taken off the bill as an apology a staff member swore at him, told him to pay the full price and to leave.

He also alleges a man who claimed he was an “investor in the restaurant” swore at him and told him to pay the full price.

Mr May said: “I refused to pay the bill as I had been insulted, then they threatened me with the police and I told them to call, whilst I stood for a few minutes, and then I began to walk to the exit.

“I was then called names like ‘a thieving scumbag’ as I stood in the doorway, while this so-called investor stood outside the door.

(Image: derbytelegraph.co.uk)

“Not knowing what my rights were on this, I went and paid the bill as I wouldn’t want to break the law.”

Mr May and his partner wrote negative reviews on TripAdvisor and Facebook, where the restaurant wrote back and posted images of the couple.

It added: "People like you deserve to be shown up.

“Do normal people try and leave a restaurant without paying? You were chased outside by customers that heard the way you behaved to the staff and heard you in the dining room acting strange.

“When you were threatened with being put on Facebook you came back and paid the little amount that it cost you to be served at our restaurant – and you still tried to avoid paying!”

(Image: derbytelegraph.co.uk)

After Mr May's partner pointed out that it could be a breach of privacy laws, the restaurant replied: “What GDPR? You come in to our restaurant and cause trouble and walk out without paying and you think this is normal?

“Of course we are going to put videos and pics of the event.

“By the way, we only have decent customers come in - we very quickly make sure we do not accept people like your friends.”

Mr May and his partner claim their reputations have been damaged and there could have been a breach of General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) privacy laws.

They have complained to the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO).

Mr Palermo said he did not believe that the restaurant had breached any laws by posting CCTV images of the customers.

He claimed: “The customer caused problems in the restaurant. They were being very rude to the staff.

“They didn’t want to pay. It’s not fair. It’s not correct. It’s not a moral thing.”

He added: "The customers had gone outside. They walked outside the door. They left with their coats on. They told everyone they were leaving.”

Mr Palermo denied that the man who intervened was an “investor” and claimed the man was just a customer.

An ICO spokesman said: "Organisations that process personal data, including CCTV footage of identifiable individuals, need to ensure they comply with their obligations under data protection law.

“This includes letting people know that you are collecting the footage, keeping the images secure, and only disclosing the images when it is necessary to do so.”

La Pizza has been accused of being "aggressive" when responding to customer complaints online.

On at least two occasions it has posted screen grabs of a customer's Facebook page and posted them in comments under the reviews.

It told customer Daniel Bruckshaw after he complained: “Please don’t pop in again or call either. We do not accept aggressive customers. Cancel our number. Thank you.”

Mr Bruckshaw replied: “Aggressive?! Eh? I think you’ve misunderstood my tone! Just providing some feedback...wow.”

If a customer is unhappy with their food or service at a restaurant, the Consumer Rights Act may give them the right to a discount or refund, according to legal expert In Brief.

Customers are entitled to expect food "provided with reasonable care and skill", it said.
description: Arron May says he and his partner paid the full £30 bill after waiting almost two hours - but La Pizza in Derby has posted CCTV images on Facebook and accused them of trying to do a runner
